SafetyInspectionBy: State of Florida Division of Emergency Management

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Stanton Clean Energy location at 5150 South Alafaya Trail in Orlando, Orange County, Florida, includes, a 680 MW combined cycle, located to the north of the coal fired units is jointly owned by Stanton Clean Energy, LLC, the Orlando Utilities Commission, the Kissimmee Utility Authority, and the Florida Municipal Power Agency. The unit is operated by Stanton Clean Energy, LLC. Employee safety and health is a fundamental value of Stanton Clean Energy, LLC. It is the policy of the facility to provide and maintain safe working conditions and to operate and manage facilities in a manner that protects the environment and meets or surpasses all federal, state, and local environmental regulations. Stanton Clean Energy Center has a safety program designed to ensure that employees and contractors are working in a safe environment. The program includes training, operating and maintenance procedures, as well as auditing and incident investigation procedures. Stanton Clean Energy Center has one anhydrous ammonia process that is covered under the Risk Management Plan (RMP) regulations, 40 CFR Part 68, as a Program level 3 process. For this reason, an RMP has been developed describing Stanton accidental release prevention program and providing chemical specific prevention steps for handling anhydrous ammonia.  The anhydrous ammonia process at Stanton has not had any reportable releases over the past 5 years. Stanton Clean Energy Center has developed an emergency response plan that complies with

29 CFR Part 1910.38 to protect the public health and the environment. This plan includes procedures for notifying the public in the event of an accidental release, procedures for the use and maintenance of response equipment, employee training, and procedures to review and update the plan. The Orange County Fire Department has visited the site and has been made aware of the facility's emergency response procedure. Emergency notification will be made by dialing 911 for notification to t
he Orange County Hazardous Materials team. Stanton conducts internal audits of the facilities RMP/PSM program and develops a scheduled action item plan for any recommended improvements.
